1.  ![Image 22: Ruben Amorim Manager of Manchester United during the UEFA Europa League 2024/25 League Phase MD5 training and press conference at Carrington Training Ground on November 27, 2024](https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/ace/standard/640/cpsprodpb/abf0/live/64ff98c0-af33-11ef-bf13-0d5fafac0b95.jpg.webp)Image source, Getty Images
    
    BBC Sport presenter Mark Chapman has been getting to know Manchester United boss Ruben Amorim in an exclusive Football Focus interview, with the Portuguese manager explaining why he appears to be "very relaxed" in his new job.
    
    "I will be OK - no matter what," Amorim said. "In this stage of my life, I will be OK so that's why I am relaxed.
    
    "Everybody says to me: 'This will change me'. This will not change me.
    
    "If something happens, I will be frustrated for a while but I know I will recover. But I believe that we are going to succeed.
    
    "I'm ready. When I had this invitation, I felt that it was really hard to leave my players at Sporting. But, when I had this opportunity, I felt I had to do this \[and make the move\].
    
    "Maybe it is destiny and I will be a little bit lucky in the beginning and then everything is going to be fine."
    
    Watch the full interview with Ruben Amorim on [Football Focus on iPlayer](https://www.bbc.co.uk/iplayer/episodes/b006m8tc/football-focus) or listen to the special [Football Daily podcast on BBC Sounds](https://www.bbc.co.uk/sounds/play/p0k7y4sr)
    
    ![Image 23: Watch on BBC iPlayer banner](https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/ace/standard/640/cpsprodpb/bee0/live/08dcdea0-af28-11ef-8ab9-9192db313061.jpg.webp)
    
    ![Image 24: BBC Sounds banner](https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/ace/standard/640/cpsprodpb/974d/live/fe40f530-af27-11ef-bdf5-b7cb2fa86e10.jpg.webp)

3.  ![Image 25: Ruben Amorim, head coach of Manchester United, during the UEFA Europa League 2024/25 League Phase MD5 match between Manchester United and FK Bodo/Glimt at Old Trafford](https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/ace/standard/640/cpsprodpb/1a87/live/b06baf40-af26-11ef-907d-d11d58b97d6a.jpg.webp)Image source, Getty Images
    
    Ruben Amorim has become the latest manager to be tasked with restoring Manchester United's on-pitch fortunes.
    
    The club paid £11m to Portuguese club Sporting to recruit the 39-year-old and his staff, making him the sixth permanent manager since Sir Alex Ferguson's illustrious 26-year reign ended with his retirement in 2013.
    
    After a draw at Ipswich and a win against Bodo/Glimt in his first two games, his side host Everton on Sunday (13:30 GMT).
    
    BBC Sport presenter Mark Chapman caught up with the Portuguese manager on Football Focus, firstly asking him if he is already feeling a connection with the Manchester United fans.
    
    "Yes for sure, I feel that" Amorim revealed. "Maybe because I'm a little bit of an emotional person. I can transmit that, even in interviews, I think.
    
    "Maybe because I am different from the last coach and this can bring a different connection with the next guy.
    
    "I believe that I am the right guy. People always believe the next guy is the right guy. We always have this feeling.
    
    "To maintain this feeling, we have to play better and win games and be really honest with the supporters.
    
    "If you are honest and direct with the supporters - maybe you don't always say the popular thing - you can create a better connection."
    
    Watch the full interview with Ruben Amorim on [Football Focus on iPlayer](https://www.bbc.co.uk/iplayer/episodes/b006m8tc/football-focus) or listen to the special [Football Daily podcast on BBC Sounds](https://www.bbc.co.uk/sounds/play/p0k7y4sr)

    ![Image 28: Ruben Amorim](https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/ace/standard/480/cpsprodpb/a5a6/live/468b4f00-ae7b-11ef-93a6-9fd2d3586a96.jpg)
    
7.  ![Image 30: Mason Mount warms up before a Manchester United match](https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/ace/standard/640/cpsprodpb/eca4/live/2bd50e50-ae29-11ef-be95-a1f725d18284.jpg.webp)Image source, PA Media
    
    Mason Mount is a "proper footballer" who wants to succeed at Manchester United, says head coach Ruben Amorim.
    
    Mount, 25, joined from [Chelsea](https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/teams/chelsea) in the summer of 2023 but his time at Old Trafford so far has been hampered by injury issues.
    
    He started against Bodo/Glimt and played for an hour of Thursday's Europa League victory.
    
    Amorim talked about his "belief" in Mount and said of the England midfielder: "The first thing is he's working really hard. Then you have to understand the human also - he wants this really badly, and that is the most important thing.
    
    "He has proved he is a really talented player. He was a European champion, so we believe in him a lot.
    
    "He has to stay fit and, like all the guys in the team, they are quality players, they have to improve and believe in themselves.
    
    "On Thursday he did a great job. You see some moments and details where you can see that Mason is a proper footballer. We believe in him a lot and I especially believe a lot in Mason."
    
    After a draw at [Ipswich](https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/teams/ipswich-town) in his first game in charge, Amorim is hopeful of a first Premier League win as United boss against [Everton](https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/teams/everton) on Sunday (13:30 GMT).
    
    "It's going to be a different match with a lot of fighting for long balls and second balls," he added.
    
    "They have a quality coach who understands the league and understands the moment of the opponent. We need to have the ball because we have a short time to recover.
    
    "I hope for a win and I hope to see different things in my team improve, like we did from Ipswich to now, against Everton, without training. I expect to see different things and better things."
    
    [Follow all of Friday's Premier League news conferences and the rest of the day's football news](https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/live/cy0gx81v9wlt)

    Manchester United have scored 13 goals from an xG of 18.3 in the Premier League this term, netting about five goals fewer than the quality of their chances suggests they should have. No team is underperforming compared to their xG more than the Red Devils.

10.  ![Image 35: Your views banner](https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/ace/standard/640/cpsprodpb/2f7f/live/95709000-0915-11ef-bee9-6125e244a4cd.jpg.webp)
    
    ![Image 36: i sport page and Telegraph sport page](https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/ace/standard/640/cpsprodpb/a5e5/live/b450da90-ae27-11ef-8ab9-9192db313061.png.webp)
    
    We asked for your thoughts after Thursday's Europa League game between Manchester United and Bodo/Glimt.
    
    Here are some of your comments:
    
    **Mike:** It's still early days and improvements are needed, but we are seeing fluid and attacking football return. Garnacho can't cross or shoot. Bodo/Glimt should wrap up their second successive domestic title at the weekend - they would have destroyed an Erik ten Hag team, so they are no walkover! Great possession in positions where it mattered and 20 shots! Hojlund was great.
    
    **Adam:** Taking the lead so early and then throwing it away to go 2-1 down so soon after just shows the frailty of the new system. We were exposed too often but, thankfully, they weren't the strongest of teams so we got off lightly. The major positive of the night has to be Hojlund. He is showing that if you feed him properly, he will do the rest!
    
    **Amogh:** Ruben Amorim showed he is decisive with substitutions and tactically flexible. My worry is that he doesn't have the players to play the system that he wants to play, and that means people playing out of position and not to their strengths. You can get away with that against a mid-table team, but not against a top eight team in the Premier League.
    
    **Brendan:** Ugarte is the glue that keeps this team together. He is a similar player to Roy Keane - impressive. Malacia had so much ball but he was not able to cope with or penetrate the defence. Shaw was dependable as usual. Rashford, regretfully, is a total lost cause and he needs to move on.
    
    **Alex:** Positive signs, definitely, but we have to make sure we don't get too excited. The great thing is that we are starting to see an identity within this team, which we haven't seen in a very long time. I'm very interested to see where we go from here and what our optimal line-up will be.
    
    ![Image 37: An image detailing how to follow your Premier League team on BBC Sport: "On the app? Tap the bell icon to get news about your club sent to you. Signed in on a browser? Hit 'Follow' to stay up to date.](https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/ace/standard/640/cpsprodpb/51a6/live/913754d0-476b-11ef-96a8-e710c6bfc866.jpg.webp)

12.  [### 00:06 29 NovemberAmorim enjoys 'special' first Man Utd win despite 'anxiety', published at 00:06 29 NovemberAmorim enjoys 'special' first Man Utd win despite 'anxiety'](https://www.bbc.com/sport/football/articles/c5yg10nxgd1o)
    
    *   Attribution
        
        [Man Utd](https://www.bbc.com/sport/football/teams/manchester-united)
        
    
    *   Comments
        
        [780](https://www.bbc.com/sport/football/articles/c5yg10nxgd1o#comments)
        
    
    ![Image 39: Ruben Amorim](https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/ace/standard/480/cpsprodpb/c6a9/live/473de420-ade1-11ef-bdf5-b7cb2fa86e10.jpg)
    
13.  ![Image 41: Ruben Amorim applauds the fans](https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/ace/standard/640/cpsprodpb/7ab9/live/71841f00-add8-11ef-a053-3198324bb252.jpg.webp)Image source, Getty Images
    
    **Manchester United manager Ruben Amorim, speaking to TNT Sports**: "Of course, I see what what everybody sees, good moments, difficult moments.
    
    "There was some confusion in the end trying to hold the result, but the lads did a great job. They ran, they pressed, they tried to do the things we have worked on in the last three days and we won!
    
    "Half of the stadium doesn't know me. I came from Portugal and I did nothing for this club. Yet, the way they make me feel at home is special.
    
    "I will keep this to the end of my career."
    
    **On the game:** "Like a real ride. We started well, but then suffered two goals in two transitions. I like the way the players tried to play our game.
    
    "Sometimes we won the ball and have had problems in the past giving the ball away too much - the mindset is keeping the ball.
    
    "They are really trying and I think we deserved the win."
    
14.  ![Image 42: Rasmus Hojlund scores](https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/ace/standard/640/cpsprodpb/a395/live/88f5d1c0-add7-11ef-a053-3198324bb252.jpg.webp)Image source, Getty Images
    
    Twenty-one-year-old Rasmus Hojlund has scored eight major European goals for Manchester United - the only players to score more aged 21 or younger for the club are Marcus Rashford and Wayne Rooney (nine each).
    
15.  ![Image 43: Rasmus Hojlund scores Manchester United's third goal](https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/ace/standard/640/cpsprodpb/9ea4/live/1e53ff90-add7-11ef-a053-3198324bb252.jpg.webp)Image source, Getty Images
    
    **Manchester United double goalscorer Rasmus Hojlund to TNT Sports:** "It was a little bit of a bad start but we came back and showed character. We want to make sure these games don't get too exciting. But it's all about the three points."
    
    **On Ruben Amorim encouraging a high press:** "He told me not to think too much about the guys behind me and just work on what I can see in front of me. We saw that with the first goal.
    
    "Obviously it's going to take time \[to adjust to his style\] but we can already see some patterns. Now it's time for us to build. For me this system reminds me of how I played in a 3-4-3 at Atalanta. It suits me well."
    
16.  ![Image 44: Alejandro Garnacho scores](https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/ace/standard/640/cpsprodpb/5f1d/live/b4c603d0-add5-11ef-a053-3198324bb252.jpg.webp)Image source, Getty Images
    
    In Manchester United's first two games under Ruben Amorim, they have opened the scoring in 81 seconds at [Ipswich](https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/teams/ipswich-town) and in 48 seconds against Bodo/Glimt.
    
    Alejandro Garnacho's tap-in, is the first time United have scored in the opening minute of a major European game since March 1991, when Brian McClair opened the scoring against Montpellier in a Uefa Cup Winners' Cup.

20.  **Simon Stone**  
    Chief football news reporter
    
    ![Image 50: Bodo/Glimt supporters wave scarves](https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/ace/standard/640/cpsprodpb/0baa/live/ed0e8020-acc5-11ef-8c4f-d52b39c994e1.jpg.webp)Image source, Getty Images
    
    Norwegian side Bodo/Glimt flew into Manchester on Wednesday before the Europa League match with Manchester United at Old Trafford.
    
    While Glimt are currently establishing themselves as Norway's top team, that has not always been the case.
    
    Sporting director Havard Sakariassen used to be a player at the club and he remembered a period where the squad had to wash their own kit.
    
    "If you go back to the year in 2009-2011, the club was struggling really hard financially," he said.
    
    "I had my last season in 2011 as a player. In mid-season that year I quit. I was old and not any good. I left the changing room and went upstairs.
    
    "At that time the club was in such bad conditions that we didn't have a kit manager. We washed our training gear at home and came to training already dressed. That was the situation at Bodo/Glimt in 2011.
    
    "We had one person working for the A team that autumn. That was me. I was the kit man."
    
    Even though the Norwegian champions accept they can never come close to matching the financial muscle Premier League clubs receive, they do not travel to Manchester without belief of causing a shock.
    
    "We don't have the resources you see at top clubs in England," Sakariassen added. "We will never, ever be able to compete with that.
    
    "But we truly believe in development and that we can get the potential out of the players we have here. If we can do that, as individuals and as a team, it is huge. Then you can make a great team and it goes a long way.
    
    "Maybe I am naive. But in a single match like on Thursday, I think we will be able to compete against Manchester United and have a great performance at Old Trafford."
    
21.  ![Image 51: Fara Williams, BBC Sport columnist banner](https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/ace/standard/640/cpsprodpb/28f5/live/41e249b0-6e9b-11ef-b282-4535eb84fe4b.jpg.webp)
    
    ![Image 52: Marcus Rashford looks down during match](https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/ace/standard/640/cpsprodpb/6ca1/live/9deedbb0-accb-11ef-9567-e3ed3a4de1fc.jpg.webp)Image source, Getty Images
    
    The Ruben Amorim system can definitely work for Marcus Rashford but he is going to have to change his mentality.
    
    From the outside, you try to read body language and, while we may not always read it correctly, Rashford does not look happy.
    
    Look at the 3-4-3 system, the only position I think he can fit into is the number nine role that he played in at the weekend. That means in terms of his mentality, and maybe his attitude, a little bit is going to have to change.
    
    Once he got his goal against [Ipswich](http://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/teams/ipswich-town), he seemed to settle for it but when you look at how Amorim’s Sporting team's worked with and without the ball, that is something Rashford is will have learn he has to do. It is down to him as an individual to adapt.
    
    But it is sad. As an outsider looking in, it is sad to see him looking miserable and not looking like he is enjoying playing. When you feel that way you really do not get the best out of yourself.
    
    I have been there when you are at a club and you do not feel like you want to be there. It is really difficult to pick yourself up and carry on and he seems to be in that moment at United. Maybe it is time for him to move on to get back to his best because unless he changes his mentality a little bit and Amorim can get him working, then I do not see a place for him in the team.
    
    The manager will certainly want him to play. We know Rashford is a quality player on his day, we know what he can do and it is about getting him back to being the player that he can be.
    
    _Fara Williams was speaking to BBC Sport's Nicola Pearson_

23.  **Simon Stone**  
    Chief football news reporter
    
    ![Image 56: Man Utd expert view](https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/ace/standard/640/cpsprodpb/2f1e/live/21c02180-ad60-11ef-8ab9-9192db313061.jpg.webp)
    
    ![Image 57: Sir Jim Ratcliffe](https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/ace/standard/640/cpsprodpb/a0aa/live/14a49210-ad60-11ef-bef0-930d33fc9c2e.jpg.webp)Image source, PA Media
    
    These are tricky times on and off the pitch at Manchester United as the club tries to reset itself.
    
    After the discontent around the Glazer regime, most fans welcomed Sir Jim Ratcliffe's arrival as co-owner with open arms.
    
    However, the veneer is beginning to wear off and news around Old Trafford in the past 48 hours has shone a spotlight on the club in a way that is not positive for the new regime.
    
    It has long been decided more needs to be sweat out of the club to generate more income to spend on the first team.
    
    Part of this came through a mass redundancy programme, in which many long-serving and popular figures at the club - some of whom were lifelong fans - have lost their jobs.
    
    Then this week, it has been confirmed matchday prices are going up to £66, with no concessions, for tickets not already sold.
    
    At the same time, United have also revealed the cost of sacking Erik ten Hag and bringing in Ruben Amorim as head coach is in excess of £21m.
    
    The argument will clearly be that instead of targeting 'normal' workers and fans, Ratcliffe and co need to be sorting out United's terrible recruitment - which now includes their decisions given the choice to keep Ten Hag after the FA Cup final victory went wrong.
    
    It is not as linear as that obviously. But at any Premier League club, costs associated with the first-team far outweigh anything else.
    
    Getting recruitment right is imperative.

Ruben Amorim 'worry' shows size of task at Manchester United but there is no need to panic
==========================================================================================

Manchester United are just two matches into the Ruben Amorim era at Old Trafford but already the critics are circling
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Manchester United's start under Ruben Amorim has been modest to say the least.

While the change in formation and new roles for some United players has been drastic, the performances have not yet altered dramatically. At Ipswich Town, [the Reds](https://www.manchestereveningnews.co.uk/all-about/manchester-united-fc) were on fire in the opening 90 seconds but soon the frailties of the squad rose to the surface with a draw the fair result.

On Thursday night it looked for 20 minutes like it would be a bleak debut for [Amorim](https://www.manchestereveningnews.co.uk/all-about/ruben-amorim) at [Old Trafford](https://www.manchestereveningnews.co.uk/all-about/old-trafford) as Bodo/Glimt stunned the hosts with two good goals. But United settled with [Rasmus Hojlund](https://www.manchestereveningnews.co.uk/all-about/rasmus-hojlund) becoming the hero to secure a big three points in the context of their [Europa League](https://www.manchestereveningnews.co.uk/all-about/europa-league) campaign.

**READ MORE: [Amorim could unleash new midfield vs Everton](https://www.manchestereveningnews.co.uk/sport/football/football-news/ruben-amorim-could-unleash-new-30486680)**

**READ MORE: [Casemiro reveals how dressing room has reacted to Amorim](https://www.manchestereveningnews.co.uk/sport/football/football-news/casemiro-reveals-how-manchester-united-30486654)**

Neither result should have sparked too strong a reaction from supporters. Ultimately, Amorim's reign is still in its infancy so to expect drastic improvements so soon is unrealistic as is being able to draw meaningful conclusions on whether the Portuguese head coach will be a success or not.

However, that did not stop former Arsenal man Paul Merson venting his opinion on [Sky Sports' Soccer Saturday](https://www.skysports.com/soccer-saturday). "It shocked me how far they are off," he said.

"When they went 1-0 up against Ipswich within one or two minutes, you think then: 'Here we go, they are going to keep the ball and get their confidence up.' You are 1-0 up away from home, within about two or three minutes Ipswich nearly scored and it was like... there is so much work to be done.

"My biggest worry out of all of it was the interview after, when he said: 'That's it now, I have never done so many interviews, now I have got to concentrate on the team.' No, you are the manager of one of the biggest clubs in world football, you will do interviews when they ask you to do interviews and you are told to do interviews.

"That was the one worry I think they have got to cope with. When you are in Portuguese football, you will do an interview here and there and they wheel along.

  

![Image 4: Sky Sports pundit Paul Merson](https://i2-prod.manchestereveningnews.co.uk/incoming/article30487972.ece/ALTERNATES/s615b/0_GettyImages-2152069342.jpg)

Sky Sports pundit Paul Merson

"He will have the press in the palm of his hand because he is winning every week and they will want a bit of him. Now he's got to be keeping them happy at the same time."

Of course, it is a culture shock for Amorim adjusting to the demands of the [Premier League](https://www.manchestereveningnews.co.uk/all-about/premier-league) and United but there is no sign at this stage that he is either out of his depth or unable to adjust in the future. [Merson's](https://www.manchestereveningnews.co.uk/all-about/paul-merson) worries would be cause for concern two years into his reign, not two games.

Whatever happens on Sunday against Everton, it is important not to jump to conclusions. This is a long-term project not a short-term fix and United fans need not be concerned by teething issues in the team or with the manager.

**One Manchester United player has been called out by new manager Ruben Amorim following first match in the Old Trafford dugout.**

After joining from Sporting CP earlier this month, [Amorim](https://www.sportbible.com/ruben-amorim) took charge of his [first home game as United boss against Bodo/Glimt on Thursday.](https://www.sportbible.com/football/football-news/man-utd/marcus-rashford-bodo-glimt-europa-league-coach-007473-20241129)

Despite [Alejandro Garnacho](https://www.sportbible.com/alejandro-garnacho) putting the hosts ahead in thee opening minute of the match, [United](https://www.sportbible.com/manchester-united) were forced to retake the lead after visitors hit back, leading to a final score of 3-2.

Amorim's first match in charge at United was the [Premier League](https://www.sportbible.com/premier-league) clash against Ipswich Town, which ended as a 1-1 draw after [Marcus Rashford's](https://www.sportbible.com/marcus-rashford) early goal wasn't enough to seal the victory.

Speaking after the game, Amorim criticised striker Joshua Zirkzee for his performance after coming on in the 68th minute of the game.

Advert

"I think that \[decision-making\] is a concern, you don’t need to coach them at this level," Amorim told Sky Sports.

"Then you have like we are in the end of the game, we were around the box with two strikers. Josh \[Zirkzee\] has to understand that he has to go to the box to have the crosses.

"So we are doing some things that were not at the right moment, so that is something we have to address.

"Sometimes people talk about the 3-4-3, that is not the concern, the system is the system but the understanding of the game is what we have to improve a lot in this area."

Advert

![Image 1: Joshua Zirkzee has been linked with a move away from Manchester United in January. (Image: Getty)](https://images.ladbible.com/resize?type=webp&quality=70&width=3840&fit=contain&gravity=auto&url=https://images.ladbiblegroup.com/v3/assets/blta90d05ad41a54a71/bltc293c32035828ea6/674b377f18613a74d35dd7d7/GettyImages-2187166574.jpg)

Joshua Zirkzee has been linked with a move away from Manchester United in January. (Image: Getty)

Zirkzee has struggled to impress since joining United from Bologna in the summer for a fee of £34 million, scoring just one goal in his 18 appearances for the club.

His poor form has led to rumours suggesting that the Dutchman would be eager to move away from United, with [Gazzetta dello Sport](https://www.gazzetta.it/Calcio/Calciomercato/Juventus/30-11-2024/la-juve-raddoppia-con-fagioli-verso-la-francia-motta-pensa-alla-coppia-ferguson-zirkzee.shtml) reporting that he would be keen to reunite with former coach Thiago Motta at Juventus this January.

I have become a fans favourite at Manchester United but I had no idea they loved me so much
===========================================================================================

Noussair Mazraoui has quickly endeared himself to Man Utd fans and he is getting as much love from the coaching staff as the terraces.

![Image 1: Noussair Mazraoui](https://i2-prod.manchestereveningnews.co.uk/sport/football/article30482266.ece/ALTERNATES/s615/0_GettyImages-2186687482.jpg)

Noussair Mazraoui has quickly become a fans favourite at Old Trafford

![Image 2: Manchester Evening News logo - whatsapp community](https://www.manchestereveningnews.co.uk/@trinitymirrordigital/chameleon-branding/publications/men/img/icon-men.png)

Until this week, Noussair Mazraoui had never played as a centre-back before. That he has taken to a specialised role in a new system with the minimum of fuss will be no surprise to the supporters who have quickly taken the Morrocan to heart at [Old Trafford](https://www.manchestereveningnews.co.uk/all-about/old-trafford).

Mazraoui has only played 19 games for [Manchester United](https://www.manchestereveningnews.co.uk/all-about/manchester-united-fc), but he's already played four different positions. In just two games, the 27-year-old looks tailor-made for the right centre-back slot in Ruben Amorim's 3-4-3 system.

With United building play in a back three and defending as a four, Mazraoui's versatility to switch between centre-back and right-back is invaluable. Along with Bruno Fernandes, he is the only outfield player to play every minute of Amorim's first two games in charge, and the head coach likes what he sees.

**ALSO READ: [Noussair Mazraoui is doing what Manchester United said he would do](https://www.manchestereveningnews.co.uk/sport/football/noussair-mazraoui-doing-what-manchester-30477349)**

**ALSO READ: [Rasmus Hojlund responds to Gyokeres comparison and explains new role](https://www.manchestereveningnews.co.uk/sport/football/rasmus-hojlund-responds-victor-gyokeres-30476570)**

"He’s an incredible player, he’s our future," Amorim said of Mazraoui after the win against Bodo/Glimt. "He played in different positions, he always looks fresh but we have to be careful. There’s a lot of games but he’s here to stay. This kind of player is what we need."

Mazraoui has looked unflustered in adapting to a new role, and although it has changed how he sees the game, he is enjoying its benefits.

“This is the first time. It’s nice. You have to view the game differently because you are not as high up the pitch like when you are the full-back," he said.

"But you get more time on the ball and you must make the most of that in the build-up. There are some different things I have to do but it’s still the same game."

Amorim has road-tested 17 different starters in his first two games in charge, but Mazraoui seems someone set for a long-term role, with the Portuguese describing him as the type of player he needs.

“It’s a big compliment to hear the coach say that," he said. "What can I say? I try my best every day and in every game. I give my all for the team, for the coach and for the supporters.

“We are all in this together. It isn’t about one player.”

United's spending across three summer windows under Erik ten Hag hit more than £600m. Mazraoui was one of the cheaper buys, at an initial £12.8m, with a further £4.2m in add-ons, but he looks like a bargain.

Supporters have already taken him to their hearts. His combative style is celebrated on social media and his low-key passion and commitment have won over a fanbase who were disappointed by the team's start to the season.

Mazraoui underwent minor surgery after complaining of palpitations back in September, but having initially been told he would be sidelined for a few weeks, he ended up not missing a game. That is the kind of commitment that has made him such a popular figure at Old Trafford, although when that was put to him, he was unaware of his status.

“To be honest I’ve not seen a lot \[about that\], but it gives me a really good feeling to hear that about the fans. I love the fans and I always say in every interview that I give my all for them," he said.

"I hope and I think they see that, that I give my all for the badge and for the supporters. Everybody wants to go home with a win and when I can give that to them as a player and as a team that’s what you do it for."

Mazraoui has had a close-up view of Amorim's start to life at Old Trafford, with a draw against Ipswich followed by a victory against Bodo Glimt.

There have been plenty of changes as the head coach instils his 3-4-3 system into a new group of players and although Mazraoui accepts it will take time for everyone to adapt, he is confident in the player's ability to do just that.

“I think always when you want to implement a new style of play that isn’t even close to how we played before then no-one can expect us to understand everything the manager has in his mind right from the start," he said.

“So yes, of course, this is going to be a tough time - but come on, we are all top players and we play the game to win. Eventually we will get to wherever the coach wants us to be.

“We have unbelievable players. Of course we can adapt and I think we are showing that. We have to get used to the new style, but I don’t think it will take too long."

[Manchester United](https://www.manchestereveningnews.co.uk/all-about/manchester-united-fc) are set to have a busy time in the transfer window in the summer, when the team could face a big revamp under new head coach [Ruben Amorim.](https://www.manchestereveningnews.co.uk/all-about/ruben-amorim)

The Portuguese manager won his first game as manager of United on Thursday night. Along with being his first match at [Old Trafford](https://www.manchestereveningnews.co.uk/all-about/old-trafford), a 3-2 win in the [Europa League](https://www.manchestereveningnews.co.uk/all-about/europa-league) against Bode/Glimt gave Amorim his first taste of success in England.

Amorim brought along his iconic three-back formation to Manchester. It's been clear that the players are still having to get used to it. However, with all new managers, Amorim will have a list of players that he wants to bring in to suit his tactics.

**READ MORE:** [Liverpool suffer major Premier League title race injury blow ahead of Man City clash](https://www.manchestereveningnews.co.uk/sport/football/football-news/liverpool-suffer-major-premier-league-30484425)

**READ MORE:** [Why 'Netflix of Football' is a step closer after Premier League clubs make significant decision](https://www.manchestereveningnews.co.uk/sport/football/football-news/netflix-football-step-closer-after-30483231)

We have rounded up the six key possible signings that could change the dynamic of Manchester United.

### **Geovany Quenda**

The 17-year-old is a player who Amorim adores from his Sporting CP days. Quenda would be following the likes of [Cristiano Ronaldo](https://www.manchestereveningnews.co.uk/all-about/cristiano-ronaldo) and [Bruno Fernandes](https://www.manchestereveningnews.co.uk/all-about/bruno-fernandes) if he changes the green and white stripes of Libson for the red of United.

The Portuguese manager handed the youngster his debut in August and the wing-back has played every game since. Wing-backs are essential to Amorim's shape as they have the important job to manage the attack down the ring whilst still maintaining their defensive duties.

  

![Image 64: Geovany Quenda](https://i2-prod.manchestereveningnews.co.uk/incoming/article30414028.ece/ALTERNATES/s615b/1_JS350813746.jpg)

Geovany Quenda could be on his way to Manchester with both United and City believed to be keen (Image: Carlos Rodrigues/Getty Images)

The key thing with this potential signing is that Amorim trusts Quenda. Their relationship could look to build into the kind of connection Ronaldo and [Sir Alex Ferguson](https://www.manchestereveningnews.co.uk/all-about/sir-alex-ferguson) had. Reports are that the 17-year-old has a £83m release clause in his contract which could be an issue - although the MEN reported on Friday that [United representatives have already met with the player's agent Jorge Mendes ahead of a potential move.](https://www.manchestereveningnews.co.uk/sport/football/transfer-news/manchester-united-meet-geovany-quendas-30482307)

### **Christopher Nkunku**

The [Chelsea](https://www.manchestereveningnews.co.uk/all-about/chelsea-fc) forward is claimed to be a player of interest to United by [TEAMtalk](https://www.teamtalk.com/news/man-utd-transfers-rival-dortmund-frustrated-chelsea-ace-perfect-ruben-amorim-signing-sources). The French international hasn't had the easiest start to his time at the Blues. A knee injury had him out of play last season for a good chunk of the year. Now fit and ready, he is still only experiencing a small amount of minutes, mainly appearing in the Conference League.

Again, Nkunku would be an ideal move for Amorim as he has experience playing with a three back during his time at RB Leipzig. Although he is now primarily used a winger, Nkunku has had experience in a centre forward role, a position which Amorim is experimenting with as seen when he put [Marcus Rashford](https://www.manchestereveningnews.co.uk/all-about/marcus-rashford) up front against Ipswich, as well as in attacking midfield - a role former United interim boss [Ralf Rangnick previously praised him for being 'one of the best' at.](https://www.manchestereveningnews.co.uk/sport/football/transfer-news/man-united-sent-clear-53m-30468659)

A permanent move away from Chelsea looks like an unlikely scenario, however, a loan move in January could be on the table with the Frenchman unhappy in London.

### **Viktor Gyokeres**

One of the hottest strikers on the market, Gyokeres has a fantastic relationship with Amorim already from Sporting. Under the Portuguese boss, the striker managed 16 goals in 11 league games. So not only does the Swedish forward know how to play to Amorim's dynamic, but the boss understands how to get the most out of his forward.

In Amorim's first two games, he has played with two different central strikers in Rashford and [Rasmus Hojlund](https://www.manchestereveningnews.co.uk/all-about/rasmus-hojlund). Hojlund has been the most successful, grabbing a brace in the Europa League on Thursday.

Bringing the Swede into United would put the £100m+ signings of Hojlund and [Joshua Zirkzee](https://www.manchestereveningnews.co.uk/all-about/joshua-zirkzee) in jeopardy, but performances can pay.

### **Matheus Cunha**

Another striker is [Wolves](https://www.manchestereveningnews.co.uk/all-about/wolverhampton-wanderers-fc)' main man Cunha. The Midlands side have just picked up their season, grabbing their first two wins in a row recently. Now, with manager Gary O'Neil having a further understanding of where gaps may lie, bringing in reinforcements may require big names like Cunha being sold.

  

![Image 65: Matheus Cunha](https://i2-prod.manchestereveningnews.co.uk/incoming/article30467415.ece/ALTERNATES/s615b/0_GettyImages-2186769955.jpg)

Matheus Cunha has been linked with a move to Manchester United in the past (Image: Jack Thomas)

The striker had cost Wolves £43m and they will likely be looking at making a profit from the Brazilian. Although Wolves are 17th, Cunha has bagged 7 goals from 12 games, more than the likes of Ollie Watkins, Bukayo Saka and Luis Diaz.

Amorim will be smart enough to not overload his attacking options. Cunha has been known to play in attacking midfield, however, which could hint at a new role for captain Bruno Fernandes if [TBR Football reports](http://iftbrfootballreportsofunited'sinterestinthebrazilianprovetobetrue,/) of United's interest in the Brazilian prove to be true,.

### **Rayan Ait-Nouri**

It looks like it could be double Wolves' for Amorim as the Algerian star Ait-Nouri has captured his eye. The defenders contract is set to expire in the summer of 2026 with [The Sun](https://www.thesun.co.uk/sport/31913903/man-utd-amorim-transfer-wolves-ait-nouri/) claiming that he wants a move away from the club.

The Portuguese manager is certainly looking to expand his defensive options, especially those at left-back. The Wolves wing-back has proven himself a force to be reckoned with on the attack, frequently getting into a position to put a ball in the box, something that a player like Hojlund would certainly take advantage of.

An important factor is the fear of relegation for Wolves. Although they have collected a couple of wins recently, they still only sit one spot above relegation thanks to a better goal difference. It's certain that Ait-Nouri would prefer European football to Championship.

### **Verdict**

Amorim would certainly have some exciting options at his disposal should he pull off a major summer revamp at United. Should that happen, United's starting XI next season could be: Onana; Yoro, De Ligt, Martinez; Mazraoui, Fernandes, Ugarte, Ait-Nouri; Nkunku, Cunha; Gyokeres.

Premier League: 10 things to look out for this weekend
======================================================

Fraser Forster steps up for Spurs, while the threat level is at its highest for Manchester City at Anfield

* * *

1

Veltman can lead Seagulls to second
-----------------------------------

Fabian Hürzeler singled out Joël Veltman as one of the Premier League’s most underrated players as Brighton prepare to face the bottom side, Southampton, on Friday. “He knows what to do to win games,” Hürzeler said of the Netherlands defender, who has started all but one of Brighton’s league games so far. Veltman – who spent eight years at Ajax before moving to the Amex in 2020 for £900,000 – is 11 months older than his manager and his experience has proved invaluable to his side in the absence of the captain, Lewis Dunk, through injury. He is expected to return against Russell Martin’s side as Brighton attempt to record a fourth clean sheet of the league season, not to mention take the opportunity to move into second place before the rest of the weekend’s fixtures. **Ed Aarons**

* * *

*   _Brighton v Southampton, Friday 8pm (all times GMT)_
    

* * *

2

A new Foxes era under Van Nistelrooy?
-------------------------------------

Unencumbered by any previous association with Nottingham Forest, Ruud van Nistelrooy would probably be [a popular appointment at the King Power Stadium](https://www.theguardian.com/football/2024/nov/27/ruud-van-nistelrooy-set-to-succeed-steve-cooper-as-leicester-manager), with all available evidence at the time of writing suggesting the Dutchman’s first match in charge of Leicester could even be at the unlikely fortress that is the Gtech Community Stadium. During his spell as interim manager of Manchester United, Van Nistelrooy made no attempt to disguise his enthusiasm for the job and brings trophy-winning experience to Leicester having won the Dutch Cup in his sole season in charge of PSV Eindhoven. Tactically flexible with whatever players he has at his disposal, Van Nistelrooy’s preferred style is to marry quick, attacking intent with defensive solidity and could quickly endear himself to a fanbase that took no time at all to tire of Steve Cooper’s defensive approach. The approach he adopts against the side with the top flight’s best home record will be intriguing. **Barry Glendenning**

* * *

*   _Brentford v Leicester, Saturday 3pm_
    

![Image 3: Steve Cooper and Ruud van Nistelrooy during Leicester’s Carabao Cup tie with Manchester United on 30 October](https://i.guim.co.uk/img/media/081180bd48b86e5238f58c1ab37b2f705657cdde/0_125_2160_1296/master/2160.jpg?width=445&dpr=1&s=none&crop=none)[View image in fullscreen](https://www.theguardian.com/football/2024/nov/29/premier-league-10-things-to-look-out-for-this-weekend#img-2)

Ruud van Nistelrooy (right) is the frontrunner succeed Steve Cooper. Photograph: Nick Potts/PA

* * *

3

Palace keen for returns to boost chances
----------------------------------------

While the performances have improved, Oliver Glasner will be concerned that the wins have yet to materialise for Crystal Palace. The Austrian will be hoping that Eberechi Eze can make his comeback against Newcastle after a hamstring injury that has sidelined him since the [win over Aston Villa](https://www.theguardian.com/football/2024/oct/30/aston-villa-crystal-palace-carabao-cup-match-report) in the EFL Cup last month, with Adam Wharton also closing in on a return for a tricky run of fixtures over the next few weeks that includes trips to Ipswich and Brighton, and home games against Manchester City and Arsenal. A repeat of April’s 2-0 win over Newcastle at Selhurst Park courtesy of two goals from Jean-Philippe Mateta would settle the nerves in south London, with Ismaïla Sarr likely to start for a fourth successive match after his first Premier League goal, [against Villa last week](https://www.theguardian.com/football/2024/nov/23/aston-villa-crystal-palace-premier-league-match-report). **EA**

* * *

*   _Crystal Palace v Newcastle, Saturday 3pm_
    

* * *

4

Old-school strikers at City Ground
----------------------------------

Having suffered back-to-back losses for the first time this season, [Nottingham Forest](https://www.theguardian.com/football/nottinghamforest) welcome Ipswich to the City Ground and will be hoping to rediscover the defensive mojo that served them so well before their recent reverses. After conceding only seven goals in their opening 10 matches of the campaign, Nuno Espírito Santo’s side have shipped six in their past two and, in Liam Delap, Forest’s central defensive duo of Murillo and Nikola Milenkovic will have to deal with quite the handful. Strong as a bull and a terrific ball-carrier who is as fast as he is fearless, the Ipswich striker’s battle against one of the league’s most impressive defensive partnerships this season ought to make for compelling viewing. In Chris Wood, Forest have a comparatively elderly bulldozer of their own and with both centre-forwards in form and responsible for half their sides’ combined Premier League goal tally of 28, this could be a classic battle of the big men. **BG**

* * *

*   _Nottingham Forest v Ipswich, Saturday 3pm_
    

![Image 4: Liam Delap of Ipswich tussles with Matthijs de Ligt of Manchester tussle during their 1-1 draw](https://i.guim.co.uk/img/media/223aa2aeb4a34d8fde99b58a84e02280a83ae74b/0_151_2946_1768/master/2946.jpg?width=445&dpr=1&s=none&crop=none)[View image in fullscreen](https://www.theguardian.com/football/2024/nov/29/premier-league-10-things-to-look-out-for-this-weekend#img-3)

Liam Delap has proven a handful for Premier League defences this season. Photograph: Michael Zemanek/Shutterstock

* * *

5

Cunha gives improving Wolves bite
---------------------------------

Wolves’ top-flight matches have seen 48 goals this season, more than any other team, but more important for Gary O’Neil his side have proved the entertainers in recent weeks. Wolves have scored six goals across their past two matches, Matheus Cunha contributing half of them, but in truth their ability to score was never the primary source of concern. Only Mohamed Salah, Erling Haaland, Cole Palmer and Bukayo Saka this season have been involved in more goals than Cunha, who has provided seven goals and three assists. Wolves have kept a sole clean sheet in the league and, out of necessity, their captain, Mario Lemina, dropped to centre-back in the [victory against Fulham](https://www.theguardian.com/football/2024/nov/23/fulham-wolves-premier-league-match-report) last time out. With Santiago Bueno and Craig Dawson returning to fitness before hosting Bournemouth, suddenly Wolves are looking up. Andoni Iraola knows all about that, having kicked off the month by [beating Manchester City](https://www.theguardian.com/football/2024/nov/02/bournemouth-manchester-city-premier-league-match-report). **Ben Fisher**

* * *

*   _Wolves v Bournemouth, Saturday 3pm_
    

* * *

6

Soler offers ray of light for West Ham
--------------------------------------

There was not unanimous agreement at West Ham over the decision to sign Carlos Soler on loan from Paris Saint-Germain last summer. Julen Lopetegui wanted the Spain midfielder but others were not as convinced. Some in the recruitment department had eyes on Chelsea’s Carney Chukwuemeka. Yet Lopetegui got his way and the first sign that he might have made the right call came in [West Ham’s win at Newcastle](https://www.theguardian.com/football/2024/nov/25/newcastle-west-ham-premier-league-match-report) on Monday. Soler had not looked up to the pace of the Premier League previously. He was taken off at half-time against Manchester United last month, but was impressive at St James’ Park. Playing in a central role, Soler’s quick thinking in possession made West Ham slicker on the ball. Lopetegui will hope that resurgence continues against Arsenal. **Jacob Steinberg**

* * *

*   _West Ham v Arsenal, Saturday 5.30pm_
    

* * *

7

Rotation of egos a test for Maresca
-----------------------------------

It is a tricky balancing act for Enzo Maresca at Chelsea. Enzo Fernández was out for a while, then in again. The midfielder has five assists in three games, cooling talk of a departure. For Maresca, though, it is not easy to keep every member of his squad happy. João Félix looked miffed not to come off the bench against Arsenal early this month. The Portugal attacker made a surprise start [against Leicester last week](https://www.theguardian.com/football/2024/nov/23/leicester-chelsea-premier-league-match-report), with Pedro Neto unavailable, but what of Christopher Nkunku, Mykhailo Mudryk and Jadon Sancho? There have been noises in recent weeks about Nkunku getting frustrated over his lack of game time. Sancho, meanwhile, has not started in more than a month and Mudryk remains an enigma. Will there be opportunities against Aston Villa? Maresca has a lot of attacking options and things are going well at the moment, but managing the egos in his squad will challenge the Italian. **JS**

* * *

*   _Chelsea v Aston Villa, Sunday 1.30pm_
    

![Image 5: João Félix runs forward during Chelsea’s Premier League match at Leicester City](https://i.guim.co.uk/img/media/234704905d1224dc13980566592cd5fe36487d7f/3_157_2630_1578/master/2630.jpg?width=445&dpr=1&s=none&crop=none)[View image in fullscreen](https://www.theguardian.com/football/2024/nov/29/premier-league-10-things-to-look-out-for-this-weekend#img-4)

João Félix has been in and out of Chelsea’s team. Photograph: Manjit Narotra/ProSports/Shutterstock

* * *

8

Amorim hopes to flower goal desert
----------------------------------

In this third game of a nascent [Manchester United](https://www.theguardian.com/football/manchester-united) tenure, Ruben Amorim will hope to see firm signs of “the idea” of playing he references taking hold in his players. Prime in this vision has to be creating more chances because United are arid when going forward, a desert before goal, Thursday night’s 3-2 Europa League win against Bodø/Glimy notwithstanding. Sean Dyche sets his sides up pragmatically so Everton, only five points behind the hosts, will be an apt test of this. Dyche will plot to turn United over on their own patch, and with Old Trafford expectant that, finally, Amorim can be the man, this should be a riveting watch. **Jamie Jackson**

* * *

*   _Manchester United v Everton, Sunday 1.30pm_
    

* * *

9

Forster’s time to shine against Fulham
--------------------------------------

Tottenham have won six and lost five of their 12 Premier League matches this season, their only draw coming against Leicester in an opening game they might have lost but for two fine saves from Guglielmo Vicario. The Italian goalkeeper will be absent [for the foreseeable future](https://www.theguardian.com/football/2024/nov/25/shock-for-tottenham-as-guglielmo-vicario-has-surgery-on-fractured-ankle), his fractured ankle the large cloud that overshadowed Tottenham’s fine [win over Manchester City](https://www.theguardian.com/football/2024/nov/23/manchester-city-tottenham-premier-league-match-report) last weekend. The job of deputising for Vicario will presumably fall to Fraser Forster, a state of affairs that has prompted much agonising over the 36-year-old’s ability – or perceived lack thereof – to play a style of football where he is required to ping short passes to his defenders. Ange Postecoglou has dismissed any such concerns, telling reporters it is a skill more related to mindset than ability. No doubt aware of concerns over the drop-off in quality between himself and Vicario, now is the time for Tottenham’s hulking backup goalkeeper to demonstrate he can also be mentally imposing. **BG**

* * *

*   _Tottenham v Fulham, Sunday 1.30pm_
    

* * *

10

Threat level highest for Guardiola
----------------------------------

Arne Slot has brought the Midas touch to Liverpool but, of all the accomplishments in his remarkable start, none would surpass the likelihood of releasing Manchester City’s four-year grip on the Premier League title on the first day of December. The prospect of going 11 points clear of the champions with an 18th win in 20 matches under Slot makes this a hugely anticipated and consequential moment for Liverpool. Yet the stakes are even higher for City. Five defeats in six games and a late collapse to [draw against Slot’s former club Feyenoord](https://www.theguardian.com/football/2024/nov/26/manchester-city-feyenoord-champions-league-match-report) have drained belief from Pep Guardiola’s players. Without Rodri they appear as fragile as Liverpool were in the aftermath of losing Virgil van Dijk to a season-ending anterior cruciate ligament injury in 2020. Josko Gvardiol’s error-strewn performances are an added problem for Guardiola, who must decide whether to risk playing the Croatian against Mohamed Salah. City’s famed powers of recovery are merely an illusion at present. They must rediscover them at Anfield, where Guardiola has never won in front of a crowd. **Andy Hunter**

* * *

*   _Liverpool v [Manchester City](https://www.theguardian.com/football/manchestercity), Sunday 4pm_

**Subscribe to Soccer with Jonathan Wilson, a weekly newsletter from one of the world’s top soccer journalists.**

I’m lucky enough to have been able to turn a childhood soccer obsession into a 24-year career that has included 13 books, regular columns in the best publications in the world and regular namechecks on Ted Lasso.

Now, I’m writing a weekly newsletter about European football aimed at a US audience, and I hope you consider signing up for it. Each week, alongside my regular column in the Observer, the Guardian’s sister Sunday paper, I’ll be looking at the biggest stories from the weekend’s action, along with issues affecting the global game.

Subscribers can expect it in their inbox every Monday. It’s entirely free and quite straightforward to cancel, so why not subscribe now?

Jonathan Wilson

### Guardian Pick

Been to Liverpool v City 6 times - 3 home, 3 away. (W3 D3). Some great memories.... Dirk Kuyt last-minute, Steve McMahon to put us top for the Double, battering them at Maine Rd 4-1...  
Yet I think I was the most nervous of all when listening to the 2013/14 one on the radio. (3-2)

I got the cooker out and started doing a full clean, and everything, because I needed to do be doing something because of the nervous energy inside.

### Guardian Pick

The game against Ipswich is a chance to get back to winning ways after a couple of disappointing defeats. In both of those games against Newcastle and Arsenal we were second best in midfield, injuries in that area have taken their toll. Fingers crossed that MGW is able to start to give us a bit more spark and creativity in the middle of the park. I am expecting a feisty affair on the banks of the Trent on Saturday, the way Ipswich played again…

**Premier League fans have reacted on social media after watching Brighton and Hove Albion against Southampton.**

On Friday night, the [Premier League](https://www.sportbible.com/premier-league) returned at the AMEX Stadium as high-flying Seagulls welcomed the Saints.

Perhaps as expected, [Brighton](https://www.sportbible.com/brighton-and-hove-albion) dominated the match early on and went ahead in the 29th minute thanks to Kaoru Mitoma.

Advert

In the second half, [Southampton](https://www.sportbible.com/southampton) hit back with Flynn Downes scoring in the 59th minute.

Reacting on social media, fans were raving about the performance of Saints young star Tyler Dibling, who has impressed again.

One fan said: "Southampton will be relegated but Tyler Dibling will still be in the Premier League next season. What a player."

Advert

Another tweeted: "@ManUtd act quick and sign Tyler Dibling, What a baller."

A third fan added: "Tyler Dibling is one of my favourite footballers to watch right now, hope he has a great career."

Someone else wrote: "Tyler Dibling is a baller. Big money move incoming soon."

A fifth commented: "Tyler dibling is a sensational baller! what a kid!"

Advert

Another fan said: "Tyler Dibling is OUTRAGEOUS."

18-year-old Dibling impressed during last weekend's defeat against Liverpool after winning a penalty in the first half and continued his fine form at the AMEX, often carrying the ball forward for the Saints and driving at the Brighton defence.

The money raised by the increase in ticket prices at Old Trafford is expected to be in the low millions of pounds. Photograph: Adam Vaughan/EPA

Manchester United raise member ticket prices to £66 and remove concessions
==========================================================================

*   Seats had started at £40 for adults and £25 for children
*   Supporters’ trust fears big price rise next season

Manchester United have raised the cost of tickets for members to £66 and removed concession prices for the rest of this season. The decision has been greeted with dismay by the supporters’ trust, which fears this is the first step before “a significant price rise” next season.

The move comes as part of the co-owner Sir Jim Ratcliffe’s efforts to make United more financially sustainable in the face of losses. Those tickets previously started at £40 for adults and £25 for children. Of the seats available to members across the rest of the season, 97% have been sold and the money raised by the increase is expected to be in the low millions of pounds.

In the long term Ratcliffe believes more prudent investment in the football operation is the prime way to make United more financially sound. Their [debt totals £714m](https://www.theguardian.com/football/2024/nov/26/manchester-united-spent-8m-sacking-staff-in-jim-ratcliffe-cost-cutting-drive), comprising non-current borrowings of £481.7m and current borrowings of £232.3m. The latter rose from £36.5m in June’s end-of-year accounts because of United’s revolving credit ­facility, which offers access to short-term finance and, it is understood, fluctuates during the year.

A Manchester United Supporters Trust statement in response to the ticket price changes said: “The club has provided zero consultation on the matter, neither with the forum nor the Fan Advisory Board nor MUST. We were simply informed of the decision that there will be price rises affecting certain fans that are ‘urgently needed’ to address profitability and sustainability concerns.

“There is a risk that this is only the opening salvo of what will surely be massive pressure to implement a significant price rise for next season. Once they have got used to charging £132 for a parent and child to come to \[Old Trafford\], will they really go back to the old pricing levels for next season?”

[skip past newsletter promotion](https://www.theguardian.com/football/2024/nov/27/manchester-united-raise-member-ticket-prices-remove-concessions#EmailSignup-skip-link-5)after newsletter promotion

United and Everton fans will stage a protest against ticket prices before their Premier League clash on Sunday. Supporters are being asked to gather next to the trinity statue outside Old Trafford to support the Football Supporters’ Association’s Stop Exploiting Loyalty campaign. As well as increasing prices generally, fans are unhappy about the removal of concession tickets for certain groups.

[View image in fullscreen](https://www.theguardian.com/football/2024/nov/27/bodo-glimt-manchester-united-europa-league#img-1)

Bodø/Glimt players celebrate at the Stadio Olimpico after a 2-2 draw with Roma in November 2021. The Norwegian side had won 6-1 at home. Photograph: AllShotLive/Action Plus/Shutterstock

Bodø/Glimt: from Arctic football outpost to centre stage at Old Trafford
========================================================================

‘It’s been quite a journey,’ says midfielder Ulrik Saltnes of the Norwegian club’s rise, an example across Scandinavia

Back in 2011, Bodø/Glimt were cash-strapped and forced into a routine beloved of park footballers. They were labouring in Norway’s second tier and – as their sporting director, Håvard Sakariassen, puts it – had “hit the wall”. Those long trips from inside the Arctic Circle feel even more onerous when you are doing everything yourself and, as they prepare to visit [Manchester United](https://www.theguardian.com/football/manchester-united), they would be forgiven a moment to marvel at how the picture has transformed.

“We didn’t have a kit manager so we washed our kit at home and came to training already dressed,” says Sakariassen, who had recently quit as a player and found himself taking de facto responsibility for managing the team’s equipment. “To compare that to our resources today, it is a totally different world.”

[![Image 3: Pep Guardiola with a cut on his nose during Manchester City’s game against Feyenoord](https://i.guim.co.uk/img/media/d7369a3dd7b0d008ed4d5158fa9d9630615beaa6/573_362_3539_2124/master/3539.jpg?width=460&quality=85&auto=format&fit=max&s=e9e9c20dceee2bc569435916a8ad8fd7) Pep Guardiola did not intend to ‘make light of self-harm’ when explaining cut Read more](https://www.theguardian.com/football/2024/nov/27/ilkay-gundogan-describes-manchester-citys-miserable-form-as-inexplicable)

It says everything that, when Bodø/Glimt walk out at Old Trafford, they will neither look nor feel out of place. This is their fifth successive season of European football and they have racked up the scalps. A Roma team managed by José Mourinho were famously [thrashed 6-1](https://www.theguardian.com/football/2021/oct/21/europa-conference-league-roma-bodo-glimt-roundup) at their Aspmyra Stadion in the 2021-22 Conference League. [Celtic](https://www.theguardian.com/football/2022/feb/24/bodo-glimt-celtic-europa-conference-league-play-off-second-leg-match-report) and, in the Europa League this season, [Porto are among](https://www.theguardian.com/football/2024/sep/25/european-football-porto-lose-to-bodglimt-as-lazio-beat-dynamo-kyiv) a string of other victims. [Arsenal were run mightily close](https://www.theguardian.com/football/2022/oct/13/bodo-glimt-arsenal-europa-league-match-report) when they visited two years ago. Whereas once there was novelty value in seeing a club from northern Europe’s furthest reaches, and a home town of fewer than 50,000 inhabitants, bloodying big-name noses, they now feel like a staple.

“It’s been quite a journey,” says Ulrik Saltnes, a long-serving midfielder who has made 370 appearances since joining in those days when a return to the top flight seemed some way off. “It’s almost hard to imagine really. Everything was so much smaller. There were so fewer people and the level was completely different. From being a team bouncing up and down the leagues to being a stable team in Europe every season since 2020, it’s just not comparable at all.”

That stability has coincided with the tenure of Kjetil Knutsen, a 56-year-old manager who has been linked with Premier League jobs but remains at the helm of Norway’s dominant force. [Bodø/Glimt](https://www.theguardian.com/football/bodoglimt) had never won an Eliteserien title until four years ago, when they streaked away at the top by 19 points. They have claimed two more and, as long as they beat Lillestrøm in a grandstand finale to the domestic campaign on Sunday, will add another.

It has been a triumph of club‑building: a success story unalloyed by wealthy backers or reckless gambles. Bodø/Glimt picked a proactive, progressive style of football and stuck with it, recruiting imaginatively while sticking firmly to their local roots. Bayern Leverkusen’s Nigeria striker Victor Boniface cut his teeth there but the overwhelming majority of Knutsen’s squad is Norwegian. They have been able to reinvest several hefty transfer fees but, as Sakariassen says: “We don’t see ourselves as a selling club.”

![Image 4: Jens Hauge celebrates scoring Bodø/Glimt’s third goal against Porto in September](https://i.guim.co.uk/img/media/4794853632d3b390a1b6733ec662bbeae4d9cf83/0_16_4947_2968/master/4947.jpg?width=445&dpr=1&s=none&crop=none)[View image in fullscreen](https://www.theguardian.com/football/2024/nov/27/bodo-glimt-manchester-united-europa-league#img-2)

Jens Hauge celebrates scoring Bodø/Glimt’s third goal against Porto in September’s 3-2 win. Photograph: NTB/Reuters

Instead they are driven by process. “We don’t have any goals in the club,” Sakariassen says. “We don’t, before the season, say: ‘Our aim is to become No 1 or 2.’ Or: ‘We’re going to win 80% of the home games.’ We threw that in the bin six years ago. We just work on trying to get better every day, doing the smart things, just working hard and only having one focus: to get the product to get better.”

They have succeeded in that. Outwardly bigger clubs in Scandinavia readily accept Bodø/Glimt have become a model for how clubs in the region might thrive. A region whose clubs’ influence on the continental stage has faded is represented by a standard bearer few could have expected. It would be a welcome bonus for Sakariassen and his cohort if they could help raise the levels of all around them. “I think you will see Norwegian teams doing well in future,” he says. “We push each other.”

Saltnes points out that domestic opponents have found ways to tackle Bodø/Glimt that European rivals are yet to grasp. The tightness of this year’s title race, Brann poised a point behind, suggests so. Last year Knutsen’s team finished nine points clear of the same opponents so perhaps they will not become the kind of wrecking ball that has dominated similarly sized championships while giving little to the wider ecosystem.

[skip past newsletter promotion](https://www.theguardian.com/football/2024/nov/27/bodo-glimt-manchester-united-europa-league#EmailSignup-skip-link-11)after newsletter promotion

The focus, though, remains on themselves. Bodø/Glimt’s next local project will be to build a new stadium, although nothing beyond their means. The charmingly atmospheric Aspmyra will be replaced by a slightly bigger 10,000-capacity venue. It will surely host Champions League football at some stage. They should have made a remarkable debut in this season’s group phase but, having taken a two-goal lead against Red Star Belgrade in the playoffs, were consigned to a 3-2 aggregate defeat.

Such a close-run thing was a further indicator of their progress. Performing at Old Trafford will be, too, and there will be some personal significance for Sakariassen, who admits to being one of the many Norwegians who followed United as a youngster. The main source of pride, though, comes from putting his home town near the centre ofon the European map against all odds.

“When I travel around Europe it’s weird for me, coming from Bodø and knowing the history that we are a small club, that everyone knows us. It’s amazing for us, and also to see the impact the club has in Bodø, in the north of Norway and also in Norway. It’s really extraordinary for me as a Bodø/Glimt boy.”

I’m lucky enough to have been able to turn a childhood soccer obsession into a 24-year career that has included 13 books, regular columns in the best publications in the world and regular namechecks on Ted Lasso.

Now, I’m writing a weekly newsletter about European football aimed at a US audience, and I hope you consider signing up for it. Each week, alongside my regular column in the Observer, the Guardian’s sister Sunday paper, I’ll be looking at the biggest stories from the weekend’s action, along with issues affecting the global game.

Subscribers can expect it in their inbox every Monday. It’s entirely free and quite straightforward to cancel, so why not subscribe now?

Latest updates
--------------

1.  BBC Sport presenter Mark Chapman has been getting to know Manchester United boss Ruben Amorim in an exclusive Football Focus interview, with the Portuguese manager explaining why he appears to be "very relaxed" in his new job.
    
    "I will be OK - no matter what," Amorim said. "In this stage of my life, I will be OK so that's why I am relaxed.
    
    "Everybody says to me: 'This will change me'. This will not change me.
    
    "If something happens, I will be frustrated for a while but I know I will recover. But I believe that we are going to succeed.
    
    "I'm ready. When I had this invitation, I felt that it was really hard to leave my players at Sporting. But, when I had this opportunity, I felt I had to do this [and make the move].
    
    "Maybe it is destiny and I will be a little bit lucky in the beginning and then everything is going to be fine."
    
2.  **Ruben Amorim has become the latest manager to be tasked with restoring Manchester United's on-pitch fortunes.**
    
    The club paid £11m to Portuguese club Sporting to recruit the 39-year-old and his staff, making him the sixth permanent manager since Sir Alex Ferguson's illustrious 26-year reign ended with his retirement in 2013.
    
    After a draw at Ipswich and a win against Bodo/Glimt in his first two games, his side host Everton on Sunday (13:30 GMT).
    
3.  **On his connection with the Manchester United fans,** Amorim revealed: "Yes for sure, I feel that. Maybe because I'm a little bit of an emotional person. I can transmit that, even in interviews, I think.
    
    "Maybe because I am different from the last coach and this can bring a different connection with the next guy.
    
    "I believe that I am the right guy. People always believe the next guy is the right guy. We always have this feeling.
    
    "To maintain this feeling, we have to play better and win games and be really honest with the supporters.
    
    "If you are honest and direct with the supporters - maybe you don't always say the popular thing - you can create a better connection."
    
4.  **Mason Mount is a "proper footballer" who wants to succeed at Manchester United,** says head coach Ruben Amorim.
    
    Mount, 25, joined from Chelsea in the summer of 2023 but his time at Old Trafford so far has been hampered by injury issues.
    
    Amorim talked about his "belief" in Mount and said of the England midfielder: "The first thing is he's working really hard. Then you have to understand the human also - he wants this really badly, and that is the most important thing.
    
    "He has proved he is a really talented player. He was a European champion, so we believe in him a lot.
    
    "He has to stay fit and, like all the guys in the team, they are quality players, they have to improve and believe in themselves."
    
    "On Thursday he did a great job. You see some moments and details where you can see that Mason is a proper footballer. We believe in him a lot and I especially believe a lot in Mason."
    
5.  **Ruben Amorim, speaking to TNT Sports, stated:** "Of course, I see what everybody sees, good moments, difficult moments.
    
    "There was some confusion in the end trying to hold the result, but the lads did a great job. They ran, they pressed, they tried to do the things we have worked on in the last three days and we won!
    
    "Half of the stadium doesn't know me. I came from Portugal and I did nothing for this club. Yet, the way they make me feel at home is special.
    
    "I will keep this to the end of my career."

    # Article Text
    Noussair Mazraoui has quickly endeared himself to Man Utd fans and he is getting as much love from the coaching staff as the terraces.

Until this week, Noussair Mazraoui had never played as a centre-back before. That he has taken to a specialised role in a new system with the minimum of fuss will be no surprise to the supporters who have quickly taken the Morrocan to heart at Old Trafford.

Mazraoui has only played 19 games for Manchester United, but he's already played four different positions. In just two games, the 27-year-old looks tailor-made for the right centre-back slot in Ruben Amorim's 3-4-3 system.

With United building play in a back three and defending as a four, Mazraoui's versatility to switch between centre-back and right-back is invaluable. Along with Bruno Fernandes, he is the only outfield player to play every minute of Amorim's first two games in charge, and the head coach likes what he sees.

"He’s an incredible player, he’s our future," Amorim said of Mazraoui after the win against Bodo/Glimt. "He played in different positions, he always looks fresh but we have to be careful. There’s a lot of games but he’s here to stay. This kind of player is what we need."

Mazraoui has looked unflustered in adapting to a new role, and although it has changed how he sees the game, he is enjoying its benefits.

“This is the first time. It’s nice. You have to view the game differently because you are not as high up the pitch like when you are the full-back," he said.

"But you get more time on the ball and you must make the most of that in the build-up. There are some different things I have to do but it’s still the same game."

Amorim has road-tested 17 different starters in his first two games in charge, but Mazraoui seems someone set for a long-term role, with the Portuguese describing him as the type of player he needs.

“It’s a big compliment to hear the coach say that," he said. "What can I say? I try my best every day and in every game. I give my all for the team, for the coach and for the supporters.

“We are all in this together. It isn’t about one player.”

United's spending across three summer windows under Erik ten Hag hit more than £600m. Mazraoui was one of the cheaper buys, at an initial £12.8m, with a further £4.2m in add-ons, but he looks like a bargain.

Supporters have already taken him to their hearts. His combative style is celebrated on social media and his low-key passion and commitment have won over a fanbase who were disappointed by the team's start to the season.

Mazraoui underwent minor surgery after complaining of palpitations back in September, but having initially been told he would be sidelined for a few weeks, he ended up not missing a game. That is the kind of commitment that has made him such a popular figure at Old Trafford, although when that was put to him, he was unaware of his status.

“To be honest I’ve not seen a lot [about that], but it gives me a really good feeling to hear that about the fans. I love the fans and I always say in every interview that I give my all for them," he said.

"I hope and I think they see that, that I give my all for the badge and for the supporters. Everybody wants to go home with a win and when I can give that to them as a player and as a team that’s what you do it for."

Mazraoui has had a close-up view of Amorim's start to life at Old Trafford, with a draw against Ipswich followed by a victory against Bodo Glimt.

There have been plenty of changes as the head coach instils his 3-4-3 system into a new group of players and although Mazraoui accepts it will take time for everyone to adapt, he is confident in the player's ability to do just that.

“I think always when you want to implement a new style of play that isn’t even close to how we played before then no-one can expect us to understand everything the manager has in his mind right from the start," he said.

“So yes, of course, this is going to be a tough time - but come on, we are all top players and we play the game to win. Eventually we will get to wherever the coach wants us to be.

“We have unbelievable players. Of course we can adapt and I think we are showing that. We have to get used to the new style, but I don’t think it will take too long.

    # Article Text
    Ruben Amorim 'worry' shows size of task at Manchester United but there is no need to panic - Jack Flintham - Manchester Evening News

Manchester United are just two matches into the Ruben Amorim era at Old Trafford but already the critics are circling.

By Jack Flintham, Sport Central Audience Writer

Manchester United head coach Ruben Amorim (Image: James Gill - Danehouse/Getty Images)

Manchester United's start under Ruben Amorim has been modest to say the least.

While the change in formation and new roles for some United players has been drastic, the performances have not yet altered dramatically. At Ipswich Town, the Reds were on fire in the opening 90 seconds but soon the frailties of the squad rose to the surface with a draw the fair result.

On Thursday night it looked for 20 minutes like it would be a bleak debut for Amorim at Old Trafford as Bodo/Glimt stunned the hosts with two good goals. But United settled with Rasmus Hojlund becoming the hero to secure a big three points in the context of their Europa League campaign.

Neither result should have sparked too strong a reaction from supporters. Ultimately, Amorim's reign is still in its infancy so to expect drastic improvements so soon is unrealistic as is being able to draw meaningful conclusions on whether the Portuguese head coach will be a success or not.

However, that did not stop former Arsenal man Paul Merson venting his opinion on Sky Sports' Soccer Saturday. "It shocked me how far they are off," he said.

"When they went 1-0 up against Ipswich within one or two minutes, you think then: 'Here we go, they are going to keep the ball and get their confidence up.' You are 1-0 up away from home, within about two or three minutes Ipswich nearly scored and it was like... there is so much work to be done.

"My biggest worry out of all of it was the interview after, when he said: 'That's it now, I have never done so many interviews, now I have got to concentrate on the team.' No, you are the manager of one of the biggest clubs in world football, you will do interviews when they ask you to do interviews and you are told to do interviews.

"That was the one worry I think they have got to cope with. When you are in Portuguese football, you will do an interview here and there and they wheel along.

Of course, it is a culture shock for Amorim adjusting to the demands of the Premier League and United but there is no sign at this stage that he is either out of his depth or unable to adjust in the future. Merson's worries would be cause for concern two years into his reign, not two games.

Whatever happens on Sunday against Everton, it is important not to jump to conclusions. This is a long-term project not a short-term fix and United fans need not be concerned by teething issues in the team or with the manager.

    article_headline: Man Utd star singled out by Ruben Amorim 'decides to leave the club in January' as brutal squad cut starts
    
    # Article Text
    **One Manchester United player has been called out by new manager Ruben Amorim following first match in the Old Trafford dugout.**

After joining from Sporting CP earlier this month, [Amorim](https://www.sportbible.com/ruben-amorim) took charge of his [first home game as United boss against Bodo/Glimt on Thursday.](https://www.sportbible.com/football/football-news/man-utd/marcus-rashford-bodo-glimt-europa-league-coach-007473-20241129)

Despite [Alejandro Garnacho](https://www.sportbible.com/alejandro-garnacho) putting the hosts ahead in thee opening minute of the match, [United](https://www.sportbible.com/manchester-united) were forced to retake the lead after visitors hit back, leading to a final score of 3-2.

And in the wake of his first matches in charge of the club, Amorim has made his feelings towards one United player known after singling them out from his teammates for one issue.

Amorim's first match in charge at United was the [Premier League](https://www.sportbible.com/premier-league) clash against Ipswich Town, which ended as a 1-1 draw after [Marcus Rashford's](https://www.sportbible.com/marcus-rashford) early goal wasn't enough to seal the victory.

Speaking after the game, Amorim criticised striker Joshua Zirkzee for his performance after coming on in the 68th minute of the game.

"I think that [decision-making] is a concern, you don’t need to coach them at this level," Amorim told Sky Sports.

"Then you have like we are in the end of the game, we were around the box with two strikers. Josh [Zirkzee] has to understand that he has to go to the box to have the crosses.

"So we are doing some things that were not at the right moment, so that is something we have to address.

"Sometimes people talk about the 3-4-3, that is not the concern, the system is the system but the understanding of the game is what we have to improve a lot in this area."

Zirkzee has struggled to impress since joining United from Bologna in the summer for a fee of £34 million, scoring just one goal in his 18 appearances for the club.

His poor form has led to rumours suggesting that the Dutchman would be eager to move away from United, with [Gazzetta dello Sport](https://www.gazzetta.it/Calcio/Calciomercato/Juventus/30-11-2024/la-juve-raddoppia-con-fagioli-verso-la-francia-motta-pensa-alla-coppia-ferguson-zirkzee.shtml) reporting that he would be keen to reunite with former coach Thiago Motta at Juventus this January.
